qas.question: What are hydrogen and carbon monoxide for Lithotrophic bacteria?
How can gas methane be used in exceptional set of conditions by methanotrophic bacteria?

answers.text: both a source of electrons and a substrate for carbon anabolism

qas.question: What is the main element for aerobic photorophy?

context: Lithotrophic bacteria can use inorganic compounds as a source of energy. <a0_0>Common inorganic electron donors<a0_0/> are hydrogen, carbon monoxide, ammonia (leading to nitrification), ferrous iron and other reduced metal ions, and several reduced sulfur compounds. In unusual circumstances, the gas methane can be used by methanotrophic bacteria as <a1_0>both a source of electrons and a substrate for carbon anabolism<a1_0/>. In both aerobic phototrophy and chemolithotrophy, <a2_0>oxygen<a2_0/> is used as a terminal electron acceptor, whereas under anaerobic conditions inorganic compounds are used instead. Most lithotrophic organisms are autotrophic, whereas organotrophic organisms are heterotrophic.
